hero.title: FitGN Rail — Locking Gastronorm rails
hero.subtitle: Professional GN rail systems built in Belgium. Keep every GN pan where it belongs. FitGN Rail locks rails in bain-maries and saladettes so chefs stay focused on service — not on reseating hardware mid-rush.

problem.title: When rails slip, service slows
problem.body: Standard Gastronorm rails sit loose in bain-maries and saladettes. Each ladle bump or fast pan swap nudges them out of alignment, breaks cold chains, and forces constant resets. Tape peels off after a few washes. Result: crooked pans, inconsistent presentation, and seconds lost every service.

solution.title: Locking or magnetic — your choice
solution.body: FitGN Rail retrofits existing wells with either a mechanical click-lock or a high-grip magnetic option. Both deliver a tight, repeatable rail position from prep to close without drilling permanent holes.

features.title: Universal drop-in base
features.text: Fits GN 1/1 and GN 2/1 openings; no cutting, no welding.

features.title: Service-proof stability
features.text: Rails stay put through hard service — no more rattling or mid-rush realignment.

features.title: Hygienic by design
features.text: AISI 304/316 stainless contact surfaces, smooth edges, easy to remove and clean.

about.title: Born from a kitchen problem
about.body: In our own restaurant Fitchen in Gent, we were tired of GN rails that slipped every service. One night, founder Koen Mortier sketched a lockable version on a prep ticket. Together with Pauline De Schepper, who runs daily operations, that sketch became FitGN Rail — the first system that keeps every Gastronorm tray locked, level, and HACCP-safe.

steps.title: Drop-in base
steps.text: Set the low-profile base into the GN well — no screws, no adhesives.

steps.title: Click the rails
steps.text: Slide each rail until you feel the lock (or magnetic engagement). Everything stays aligned.

steps.title: Service & clean
steps.text: Swap pans at speed. Lift the base after service; the open profile rinses and dries fast.
